newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: RUGBY UNION-WAIKATO TORPEDO GAUTENG'S SEMIFINAL HOPES.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-WAIKATO TORPEDO GAUTENG'S SEMIFINAL HOPES.

text.p: The Waikato Chiefs dealt the Gauteng Lions a disastrous blow in the Super 12 competition on Saturday with an emphatic 47-9 win at Hamilton.
Waikato's victory was well-deserved while the Lions' chances of making the semifinals were all but dashed.
Gauteng, formerly Transvaal, now have to beat Queensland and then Natal in their last two games to stand any chance of remaining in semifinal contention.
Waikato took the lead in the 11th minute after a scrum close to the Gauteng Lions' line when No 8 Deon Muir dived over for a converted try.

Penalties were traded before Waikato eased further in front in the 28th minute with a penalty try after Gavin Johnson was penalised for failing to release the ball. Matthew Cooper converted to make it 20-6.
The Chiefs struck decisively two minutes from the break.

Blindside flanker Aaron Hopa and Muir, showing an uncanny understanding of each other's play, combined at mid-field in the Lions' half to spark a move which sent substitute left-wing Caleb Ralph in for Waikato's third converted try.

Waikato, playing exciting, crisp rugby, deservedly led 30-9 at halftime and Ralph and right-wing Scott McLeod added two more tries in the second half to stamp their authority on the match and also notch up a bonus point.
